This show did not last very long and I can understand why. It was mainly hampered by having one central idea from which it never deviated. If we were going to have one idea to follow that long, I needed one that was more than Thomas Jane becoming a male prostitute in order to supplement his income as a divorced teacher.

But the initial episodes are interesting enough. Indeed, this entire first season covers the whole idea and one could be perfectly satisfied with just it. He is extraordinarily well endowed (thus the name "Hung") which makes this sideline a natural for him. Besides that, he is very good looking and charming. Actually, this guy could get remarried so easily to a woman in his age range (40s) with a lot of money that I wondered why in the heck he didn't go that route since he was bound and determined to prostitute himself for money.

Perhaps the best part of the show though is that he is surprised to discover that women don't want any more from him than what he has on offer. He figures that unlike a female prostitute, they may actually have feelings for him. Think again. He has the exact same problem in this department that a woman does.

He also has an interesting female pimp.

His ex is remarried to a wealthy guy who has zilch other qualities. The kids are ok. That part of the show could have been eliminated without a problem.

I've never talked to any men who watched this, only women. But maybe there are guys out there who enjoyed this who simply haven't come forward. I think it was intended for a female audience though. Try it. You might like it or at least one season of it.

Hung started about the same time as True Blood season two. After the second episode I was hooked! The main character is a high school history teacher and basketball coach whose house burns down, children want to live with his ex-wife and he's broke broke broke. He meets up with a poet who he once (ahem) and together they hatch a harebrained scheme to pimp him and his ... out. Through this he has to deal with women he isn't attracted to but learns to love what's under the skin, crazy women who pay for him but not his "services" and the working in's and out's of women. Meanwhile his pimp, Tanya, is suffering as a failed poet and drowning in her own lack of love in her life. Bumps and bruises along the way but every episode bring  laughter and smiles to my face (and my husbands!).
The characters learn and even though they get a lot more bad than good cards, they always grow. I'm very pleased with the direction this new series is going and sit in anticipation every Sunday night when my little red dot that indicates my DVR is recording blinks on. Hung is a lot more than I had anticipated and am tickled with the gem found under dirty gym socks and a slathering of sexual innuendo.

Hung is an interesting show. It takes a little while to find its legs and get moving, but once it does it clips along pretty well. It's not as much of a comedy as a dramedy, and I was expecting more funny than awkward moments. While there is a good mix of both funny and awkward, there are more 'feeling sorry' moments for the lead character, Thomas Jane's Ray and Jane Adams' Tanya than anything else.
Ray starts out a bit annoying but you quickly warm up to his character. Tanya starts out endearing and a bit awkwardly cute before becoming incredibly annoying. By season 2, I was rooting for Lenore to force Tanya out of the show which really is a shame.
Anne Heche's ex-wife character is extremely hard to watch, as her interactions with her children are nails-on-chalkboard levels of cringe worthy awkwardness. Ray's children, while played as background pieces in the first few episodes, really flesh out in later episodes. They showcase a perfect bi-section of the awkwardness of adolescence, finding yourself as a teen, experimentation and body image, while playing as a nice mirror to the adult characters finding themselves, experimentation, and dealing with body image. The show doesn't play up this dichotomy, but it's nice that it exists and is written into the narrative.

This was an interesting idea for a series-and parts of it hit the mark-but other parts do not. I previously watched the series on DVD and I grew up near Detroit so there is some personal identification for me. The main character (Ray Drecker) is pretty much what you would expect-a high school athletic hero who was drafted by the Atlanta Braves, but his career was derailed by injury. He is back at his old high school teaching/coaching-he married the cheerleader-but is unhappily divorced from her and way down on his luck. He is handsome, appealing, easy going (and hung), but has limitations in his ability to relate to others-especially women. That is the real interesting part-as he becomes a small time male ho-he finds that this profession is much different for men than it is for women. He has to find a way to relate to his customers on their (female) terms or they are much less interested in his physical equipment. The series does a good job of exploring these avenues-(but many of the sideshow characters distract from that). The fiery redheaded, Lenore, is a passive-aggressive alpha manipulator. She reminds me of my ex-wives-except the actress that plays Lenore is stunningly beautiful. I fell in love with her-she is beautifully & emotionally treacherous and plays the part to alpha perfection. Tanya, the amateur pimp, has a good soul-but the character is too naive and emotional (and irritatingly skanky) to do the job she is trying to do. In real life Detroit she would be dead in about 5 minutes. But this was not real life Detroit either-it is much too white for that. The primary client in the first season (Jemma) is played very alluringly. She is setting up Ray to take an emotional fall-and he is completely outclassed (but she pays him well). The first season falls a just a little short of being great. I was looking forward to the second season-which was then uneven and too focused on the sideshow of irritating support characters.. The third season was far better and I think if the second season had been better built on the first----this show could have had a longer run. As a series it was at times erratic, boring, unrealistic, irritating. If you like to follow the the subplots you will probably find this interesting and enjoyable. If you are looking for a diet of (Cinemax) sex scenes-it likely won't be satisfactory-although there is a considerable amount of nudity.

I've recently taken to watching shows that I've shunned in the past because I felt like they were a deliberate finger in the eye to people like me who don't approve of drug abuse, drug dealing, prostitution, and what could be generally described as "people misbehaving."

But having watched "Weeds,"Breaking Bad," "Secret Diary of a Call Girl," and having enjoyed them all (and now including all three seasons of "Hung"), I've come to realize something...for the most part, "good behavior" is not cinematic.  People who lead ordinary decent lives are for the most part not terribly interesting as subjects of television dramas and movies.

So that's why I decided to give "Hung" a chance and while it will not be remembered by me decades from now as the greatest comedy-drama in cable television's history, I've enjoyed the series.

I think that's down to the leads of the series, the guy playing everyman Ray Drecker and the actress playing his hapless pimp Tanya make those characters sympathetic and plausible.  And the series manages to inject a fair amount of humor and absurdity in something that in real life is pretty sad and degrading.

And besides, all "Hung" is is a riff on one on the oldest and most successful tropes in literature...the hooker with a heart of gold...and it still works.

So if you don't mind a fair amount of lurid sexual encounters in a show (remember, it's a about a man-whore after all!), I think you will probably find "Hung" amusing and sometimes poignant.

It's not perfect...sometimes, the Tanya character comes across as such a mess, it's hard to see why her one and only "ho" would stay with her. Ann Heche's character (Ray's ex-wife) doesn't come across as terribly sympathetic (it's hard to see why Ray would pine after her).

But overall, it's good, escapist trash...and I'll be watching it when the fourth season rolls out.

Notice I said "entertainment" NOT "art."  Anyone who expects to find "art" in a cable television series needs to get their head examined.  Sure, the title and the storyline hinge upon the longstanding myth/reality (depending on which side of the fence you're on) that the better-endowed the man, the better a lover he is...but this is just an excuse for the movie, the "hook" if you will.  There are a lot of other layers to this series as well.  As far as mass entertainment goes, there is a refreshingly low percentage of cliches, stereotypes and stock characters...many scenes from "Hung" actually do contain a nice bit of originality and authenticity.

Excellent camera work and film editing, great music (especially the intro song by The Black Keys, "I'll Be Your Man"), excellent cast (including a bevy of some FINE FINE babes in various states of undress, especially Alanna Ubach, Natalie Zea and Rebecca Creskoff), and strong dialogue all make this a pleasure to watch.  AND to top off all the eye candy, there's a fair bit of social realism and cultural satire happening too.  Jane Adams, Anne Heche, and of course Thomas Janes do most of the heavy lifting, and there is often a strong "indie-film" vibe to many of the scenes.  The viewer is not constantly being challenged to suspend disbelief, in other words.  The viewer does not feel manipulated or patronized or pandered to, which is exceedingly rare in most TV and cinema offerings these days.
